note_text:
PATIENT: 68-year-old female.

INDICATION: Hemoptysis and CT chest showing a 3.5 cm right mainstem bronchial mass concerning for lung cancer.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy performed under general anesthesia via oral endotracheal tube. Vocal cords and trachea were normal. A friable, obstructing, exophytic tumor was visualized in the right mainstem bronchus with contact bleeding. Multiple endobronchial forceps biopsies were obtained from the right mainstem tumor for histology with good hemostasis after iced saline and brief suctioning. Additional protected brushings were performed from the same lesion for cytology. No BAL, transbronchial lung biopsy, TBNA, EBUS, or therapeutic tumor debulking was performed. Estimated blood loss was <10 mL. The patient was extubated in the procedure room and discharged from PACU in stable condition.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Hemoptysis and central right mainstem mass concerning for lung cancer
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma of the right mainstem bronchus

evidence.primary_indication: INDICATION section describes hemoptysis and a right mainstem mass on CT.
evidence.airway_type: Oral endotracheal tube used for airway control.
evidence.cpt_31625: Multiple endobronchial forceps biopsies were obtained from the right mainstem tumor.
evidence.cpt_31623: Protected brushings were performed from the same endobronchial lesion for cytology.

changes: Synthetic gold standard bronchoscopy case with endobronchial biopsies and brushings; no automated patches applied.

Bronchoscopy; with brushing or protected brushings

notes: Values based on 2025 Medicare national averages from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 fee_schedules (facility).
Totals do not account for MPPR, sequestration, or geographic adjustments.

rules_applied.description: When advanced sampling such as endobronchial biopsy or brushing is performed, 31622 (diagnostic bronchoscopy) is not reported separately in the same session.

narrative_paragraphs: 31625 is selected as the primary bronchoscopy code because multiple endobronchial forceps biopsies were obtained from a right mainstem tumor.
31623 is added because protected brushings were separately documented and sent for cytology from the same lesion.
A separate diagnostic bronchoscopy code 31622 is not billed because the diagnostic evaluation is inherent to the biopsy and brushing services per advanced sampling bundling rules.

rationale: Bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy (31625) and protected specimen brushings (31623) performed on a right mainstem mass.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled into the therapeutic codes.

note_text:
PATIENT: 45-year-old male.

INDICATION: Acute cough and unilateral wheeze after choking on a nut; CT with obstructing endobronchial foreign body in the right mainstem bronchus.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy performed with moderate sedation and spontaneous breathing through the native airway. A hard organic foreign body was visualized lodged in the right mainstem bronchus with surrounding edema but no active bleeding. The foreign body was grasped with forceps and removed en bloc through the bronchoscope without fragmentation. Airways were reinspected and no residual material was seen. No BAL, brushings, biopsies, EBUS, or stent placement was performed. The patient tolerated the procedure well without desaturation and was discharged home from PACU.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Suspected endobronchial foreign body with unilateral wheeze
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Endobronchial foreign body removed from right mainstem bronchus

evidence.airway_type: Bronchoscopy performed via the native airway without an endotracheal tube.
evidence.cpt_31635: A hard organic foreign body was grasped and removed en bloc from the right mainstem bronchus.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Short-term clinic follow-up and repeat chest imaging as needed.

changes: Synthetic gold standard case for bronchoscopic foreign body removal; no automated patches applied.

narrative_paragraphs: 31635 is selected because a discrete endobronchial foreign body was identified and removed under direct bronchoscopic visualization.
No brushings, biopsies, or BAL were performed; advanced sampling codes are therefore not indicated.
Per diagnostic-with-surgical rules, a separate diagnostic bronchoscopy code 31622 is not reported.

note_text:
PATIENT: 62-year-old male with suspected lung cancer.

INDICATION: PET-avid right lower paratracheal lymphadenopathy (station 4R) requiring mediastinal staging.

PROCEDURE: Linear EBUS bronchoscopy performed under general anesthesia via oral ETT. The 4R lymph node measured approximately 12 mm short axis with heterogeneous echotexture and no Doppler vessels. Using a 22-gauge EBUS needle, three passes were obtained from station 4R with good cytologic material seen on ROSE, consistent with malignant cells. No additional nodal stations were sampled. No conventional TBNA, radial EBUS, navigation bronchoscopy, or parenchymal biopsy was performed. The patient was extubated in the operating room and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: EBUS-TBNA of 4R with malignant cells consistent with lung carcinoma

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Thoracic oncology clinic for definitive staging and treatment planning.

changes: Synthetic gold standard case for limited-station linear EBUS sampling (1-2 stations).

Conventional TBNA was not performed; 31629 is not supported and would be bundled under EBUS TBNA if attempted at the same station.
No radial EBUS, navigation, or parenchymal biopsies were documented, so no additional bronchoscopy codes are assigned.

note_text:
PATIENT: 71-year-old female with suspected stage III lung cancer.

INDICATION: PET-avid mediastinal and hilar adenopathy (stations 4R, 7, and 11R) requiring comprehensive EBUS staging.

PROCEDURE: Linear EBUS bronchoscopy performed under general anesthesia with ETT. Systematic nodal survey was performed. Enlarged nodes were seen at stations 4R (15 mm), 7 (18 mm), and 11R (10 mm). Using a 22-gauge EBUS needle, three passes were obtained from each of the three stations for a total of nine passes. ROSE showed malignant cells in 4R and 7 and adequate lymphocytes in 11R. A bronchoalveolar lavage was then performed in the right lower lobe for microbiology and cytology. No transbronchial biopsies, radial EBUS, or navigational bronchoscopy were performed. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications.

registry_entry.primary_indication: PET-avid mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy requiring systematic EBUS staging
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: EBUS-TBNA with malignant cells in 4R and 7, benign 11R; BAL pending

evidence.cpt_31624: Bronchoalveolar lavage performed in the right lower lobe for microbiology and cytology.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Multidisciplinary tumor board review and definitive oncologic therapy.

narrative_paragraphs: Three nodal stations (4R, 7, 11R) were sampled with linear EBUS, supporting 31653 for 3 or more stations.
A bronchoalveolar lavage was separately documented after staging, supporting an additional 31624.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy is not separately reported because it is inherent in the EBUS staging and BAL services.

note_text:
PATIENT: 64-year-old male with central airway obstruction from endobronchial tumor.

INDICATION: Progressive dyspnea and post-obstructive pneumonia due to a right mainstem endobronchial mass.

PROCEDURE: Rigid and flexible bronchoscopy under general anesthesia. A friable intraluminal tumor was seen nearly occluding the right mainstem bronchus. Therapeutic aspiration and suctioning were used to clear copious purulent secretions. Balloon dilation was performed to facilitate stent placement. A covered metallic bronchial stent was deployed across the right mainstem bronchus with good expansion and restoration of lumen. No BLVR valves, BAL, transbronchial biopsies, or EBUS were performed. The patient remained ventilated via ETT post procedure and was admitted to the ICU.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Central airway obstruction from right mainstem tumor with post-obstructive pneumonia
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant right mainstem obstruction treated with covered bronchial stent

evidence.cpt_31645: Therapeutic aspiration used to clear copious purulent secretions from the obstructed airway.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: ICU monitoring with planned interval bronchoscopy to assess stent patency.

changes: Synthetic gold standard case for airway stent placement with therapeutic aspiration in malignant CAO.

note_text:
PATIENT: 69-year-old female with advanced emphysema.

INDICATION: Severe heterogeneous upper-lobe–predominant emphysema with hyperinflation and persistent dyspnea despite maximal medical therapy; candidate for bronchoscopic lung volume reduction.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy under general anesthesia via ETT. The right upper lobe airways were carefully inspected. Four Zephyr endobronchial valves were placed sequentially into segmental bronchi of the right upper lobe using the manufacturer deployment catheter, with good seating and immediate lobar collapse on fluoroscopy. No valves were placed in other lobes. No Chartis measurements, BAL, transbronchial biopsies, or EBUS procedures were performed during this session. The patient was extubated in PACU and admitted to telemetry for post-BLVR monitoring.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for severe upper-lobe–predominant emphysema
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Successful BLVR with Zephyr valves in the right upper lobe

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Standard BLVR pneumothorax surveillance with chest imaging and symptom monitoring.

No valves were placed in additional lobes, so a BLVR add-on code is not reported.
Chartis measurements were not performed during this session, and diagnostic bronchoscopy 31622 is not coded separately.

note_text:
PATIENT: 72-year-old male with prior BLVR in the right upper lobe.

INDICATION: Recurrent pneumonia and persistent cough attributed to migrated and occlusive right upper lobe valves; planned valve removal and airway toileting.

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy under general anesthesia via ETT. Four previously placed Zephyr valves were visualized in the right upper lobe segmental bronchi, with one partially migrated. All four valves were removed using the manufacturer retrieval forceps without complication. Extensive therapeutic aspiration and suctioning were performed to clear thick, purulent secretions from the right upper lobe and bronchus intermedius. No new valves were placed, and no biopsies, BAL, or EBUS procedures were performed. The patient was extubated and admitted for IV antibiotics.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Removal of malfunctioning BLVR valves and airway toileting for recurrent pneumonia
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Successful removal of endobronchial valves with improved airway clearance

evidence.cpt_31645: Extensive therapeutic aspiration and suctioning cleared thick purulent secretions.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Monitor for recurrent infection and reassess need for further lung volume reduction.

changes: Synthetic gold standard case for BLVR valve removal with therapeutic aspiration.

note_text:
PATIENT: 60-year-old female with recurrent unilateral pleural effusion.

INDICATION: Symptomatic right pleural effusion of unclear etiology; diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis planned.

PROCEDURE: At the bedside with the patient sitting, the right posterior hemithorax was imaged with ultrasound showing a large anechoic effusion without loculations. After marking an appropriate site, the skin was prepped and draped, and local anesthetic was infiltrated. A single thoracentesis needle and catheter were advanced into the pleural space without complication. Approximately 1,500 mL of serous fluid was removed with symptomatic relief. Opening pressure was not formally measured. No ultrasound guidance code, chest tube placement, tunneled catheter, or thoracoscopy was performed. Post-procedure lung sliding was preserved clinically and on ultrasound.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent right pleural effusion requiring diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Large right pleural effusion drained; fluid studies pending

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Outpatient follow-up with pleural fluid studies and repeat imaging as needed.

note_text:
PATIENT: 66-year-old male with complicated parapneumonic effusion.

INDICATION: Loculated right pleural effusion with residual collections after chest tube drainage; planned tunneled catheter placement and intrapleural fibrinolytic therapy.

PROCEDURE: Under ultrasound guidance, a right lateral chest wall entry site was selected and anesthetized. A tunneled indwelling pleural catheter with cuff was placed into the largest loculated collection and connected to drainage bottles, with good flow of serosanguinous fluid. Approximately 800 mL was removed at the time of placement. Through the newly placed catheter, a single dose of tPA and DNase was instilled and allowed to dwell per institutional protocol. No additional thoracentesis, thoracoscopy, or chest tube was placed. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was admitted for further intrapleural therapy.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Complicated parapneumonic effusion requiring tunneled catheter and fibrinolytics
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Indwelling tunneled pleural catheter placed with first-day intrapleural fibrinolytic instillation

evidence.cpt_32550: A tunneled indwelling pleural catheter with cuff was placed under ultrasound guidance.
evidence.cpt_32561: A first-day dose of tPA/DNase was instilled via the chest catheter for fibrinolysis.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Serial intrapleural fibrinolytic instillations and catheter drainage until radiographic improvement.

changes: Synthetic gold standard case for tunneled pleural catheter placement with first-day fibrinolytic instillation.

note_text:
PATIENT: 63-year-old female with a peripheral right lower lobe lung nodule.

INDICATION: 2.1 cm peripheral right lower lobe nodule requiring tissue diagnosis; not amenable to bronchoscopic sampling.

PROCEDURE: CT-guided percutaneous core needle biopsy of the right lower lobe nodule was performed in the prone position. Multiple 18-gauge core samples were obtained and sent for histology and culture. Immediately after the biopsy, the patient developed dyspnea and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. CT and bedside ultrasound confirmed a moderate right pneumothorax. A large-bore chest tube was placed in the right anterior axillary line, connected to a water seal drainage system with good air evacuation. The patient was admitted for chest tube management. No concurrent bronchoscopy or thoracentesis was performed.

registry_entry.primary_indication: CT-guided percutaneous biopsy of a peripheral right lower lobe lung nodule
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: CT-guided core needle biopsy of RLL nodule complicated by iatrogenic pneumothorax requiring chest tube

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Hospitalization for chest tube management and monitoring for persistent air leak.
